results.title: Lust and revenge
results.creator_credit: Illumination Films (AU), Paul Cox and Jane Ballantyne
results.brief_description: Georgina Oliphant commissions her friend Lily to create a sculpture for a new wing at the National Gallery. Her father sees it as an opportunity for a healthy tax deduction. Karl Heinz, who is chosen as the model for the sculpture, sees it as a chance to buy a cottage in Handover. His wife Celia, who is heavily involved in a New Age religious group, isn’t so thrilled. Everyone wants something but who will ultimately win? The film twists and turns towards its hilarious conclusion. Nominated for Best Director in the 1996 AFI Awards, “Lust and Revenge” is a biting satire on the arts world and the financial imperatives driving it. However, the most powerful element of the film is the development of the characters as they are drawn into this Machiavillian power game. Look out for some wonderful cameo roles, particularly from Wendy Hughes and John Hargreaves.

results.title: Lungs
results.creator_credit: Educational Media International, D Morgan and A K Lee
results.brief_description: Discusses the structure, function and mechanism of the lungs. The overall structure of the lungs and air passage is presented by means of a sheep dissection and a living lung is seen during a routine operationat a veterinary clinic. The movement of the diaphragm and ribs is clearly highlighted by X-ray.

results.title: Lunawanna kiss
results.creator_credit: James Middleton Films and James Middleton
results.brief_description: A Catholic boatman, living on a remote island off the south coast of Tasmania in 1931, falls in love with the Protestant lighthouse keeper’s daughter. Silent film with musical soundtrack composed by Franz Schubert with Christina Bush-Sigrist on violin, Sue Pickering on cello and Jody Heald on piano. Cast: Saul Darby, Lucy Gouldthorpe, Jim Higgins, Jane Byrne.

results.title: Luna, luna, luna
results.creator_credit: Francine Desbiens, ONF | NFB and Viviane Elnecave
results.brief_description: A child sleepwalks into the forest. A black vastness inhabited by night creatures throbs and chirps, croaks and gurgles. As she wades deeper into the shimmering night, the real forest and the imaginary one dissolve into each other. Apparitions and phantoms begin their nocturnal dance. The atmosphere becomes charged and witches come shrieking to life. When the fear of the night reaches its peak, the moon rises and the final lunacy begins. An animated film about a child’s reaction to the mysteries and magic of the night. Film without words. (Awards: Zagreb; Lausanne)

results.title: Lumumba
results.creator_credit: Jacques Bidou, JBA Productions, Entre Chien et Loup, Essential Filmproduktion, Velvet SA, Arte France and Raoul Peck
results.brief_description: A political thriller that is the true story of a young African leader, elected at the age of 36 to become the first Prime Minister of the newly independent state of the Congo. Patrice Lumumba (Eriq Ebouaney) in the 1950s was fifty years before his time as he was seeking the ideal of a country free of colonial rule and a true democracy but he became a victim to corruption and powerful international big business interests. The film traces his journey from humble beginnings as a beer salesman to a voice of the people and great leader, finally to his torture and assassination. Powerfully acted and empathetically realised, this story resonates on two levels both as a personal life story of the man but also as an historical political account. Winner of a Peace Award at the Political Film Festival in the United States. A French, Belgian, German, Haitian co-production. Cast includes Alex Descas, Maka Kotto, Theophile Moussa Sowie, Andre Debaar.

results.title: Lumsden
results.creator_credit: Tom Daly, ONF | NFB and Peter Raymont
results.brief_description: Lumsden, Saskatchewan, is a town of 850 citizens on a river called the Qu’Appelle. In the spring of 1974, the river doubled its volume and threatened to flood the town. The townspeople organized themselves and the whole province stood behind them. It is the story of an incredible battle against impossible odds.

results.title: Lumiere programme [Silent version]
results.brief_description: The first public film show in Great Britain was given at the Regent Street Polytechnic London, on February 20th, 1896, by the brothers August and Louis Lumiere. This film is a complete reprint of the programs shown on that occasion. It comprises the following subjects: Workers leaving the Lumiere factory; Baby at the lunch table; Demolition of a wall; Watering the gardener; Congress of Photographic Societies at Neuville-Sur-Saone, July 1895; Arrival of a train at Ciotat Station; A game of cards; A boat leaving harbour. None of these films is more than a single shot, without cutting or camera movement; their interest lay entirely in the novelty of the moving photograph.

results.title: Lumiere D'ete = Summer Light
results.brief_description:
An ex-dancer runs an isolated mountain hotel where the guests are ‘people with problems’. This melancholy allegory about characters living on the edge of a figurative and literal abyss, was made under the restrictions of Vichy France and at times threatened by censorship. Visually, [during the Occupation] the new films became more mannered and stylized, surpassing even the expressionistic vistas of ‘realisme poetique’ in their creation of visual fields removed both from every day reality and from the characters who moved within them. Some works returned to overt pictorialism of late silent film, perhaps most notably Gremillon and Prevert’s ‘Lumiere d’Ete’. Sets were often large and elaborate, despite obvious financial difficulties that this entailed in a period of limited resources. Roger Regent, one of the period’s most astute observers, spoke of the ‘decor-personnage’ (the set as character) as being an often abused cinematic cliche. If decor could frequently function as a kind of (impersonal) character, fictional beings could by the same token lapse into relative, sometimes absolute stillness, assuming the function of decor in a larger, metaphysical drama.” Reference: Alan Williams. “Republic of Image: a history of French filmmaking”. Harvard University Press, 1992

Credits: Producer, Andre Paulve ; director, Jean Gremillon ; writers, Jacques Prevert, Pierre Laroche ; photography, Louis Page ; music, Roland Manuel ; art direction, Max Douy, Louis Barsacq.
Cast: Paul Bernard, Madeleine Renaud, Pierre Brasseur, Madeleine Robinson, Raymond Aimos, Georges Marchal, Jane Marken, Charles Blavette.

results.title: Lumiere and company
results.creator_credit: Cineteve, Igeldo Komunikazioa, La Sept-Arte, Studio Canal+, Soren Staermose AB, Neal Edelstein and Fabienne Servan-Schreiber
results.brief_description:
These are the rules: No post editing; no synchronous sound; no more than three takes. The facts: only 52 seconds of film using an original restored 35mm Lumiere camera. 40 filmmakers from around the world partake in one of the most fascinating and enlightening cinematic experiments in film history, to commemorate the centennial of the Lumiere Brothers’ first motion picture. “From slapstick comedy to political propaganda, documentary realism to costume drama, the world is fleetingly captured once again. But the lens of the contemporary beholders has seen a century the Lumiere brothers could scarcely have imagined. Watching the directors it is hard to decide which side of the camera provides the greater entertainment! Who cranks the handle themselves or who insists on a full technical crew; who conquers, or cracks under the constraints is fascinating and just as illuminating as the succinct sensations they create.” - Amree Hewitt. 45th Melbourne International Film Festival, 1996.
